title: Buyers Snap Up U.S. Homes in August Amid Low Mortgage Rates
text:
U.S. home sales spiked in August as falling mortgage rates drew buyers into the market, according to a report Thursday from Redfin.



The number of homes sold in August increased 10.8% compared to a year ago, the biggest spike since March 2017, according to the listing website, which aggregates data from 217 U.S. metro areas. The cost of borrowing declined to near-historic lows in August following the Fed’s decision to cut its bench-market interest for the first time in a decade, triggering a flurry of home buyer.



More: ‘Black Friday’ of U.S. Real Estate is Next Week

But strong activity in August had a muted effect on home prices, as fears of an economic slowdown continue to weigh on the market, according to Redfin’s chief economist Daryl Fairweather.



The median home price rose to $312,200 in August, a modest 2.7% increase from a year ago.



“Global economic uncertainty and talk of a looming recession in the U.S. are staving off many aspects of a hot seller’s market—think bidding wars, fast sales and huge price escalations—at least for now,” Ms. Fairweather said in the report.



A seller’s market could be on the horizon, however. The National Association of Realtors, which put out its own report on August sales on Thursday, said that low supply may cause prices to climb out of buyers’ reach if sales activity remains high.

“Sales are up, but inventory numbers remain low and are thereby pushing up home prices,” said Lawrence Yun, NAR’s chief economist. “Homebuilders need to ramp up new housing, as the failure to increase construction will put home prices in danger of increasing at a faster pace than income.”



High demand for mortgages, which precede closings, point to growing home sales over the next few months, according to a note from Pantheon Macroeconomics on Thursday. By early 2020, Pantheon said, U.S. home sales could reach a “new post-crash high.”
